newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan Jan crude imports show shift to heavier oil.
newsitem.headline: Japan Jan crude imports show shift to heavier oil.

text.p: Japan's crude import statistics for January showed the country's growing taste for cheaper, heavier type Middle Eastern crudes, oil industry sources said on Monday.
"Heavy crudes are becoming attractive price-wise, because of the growing price difference with light crudes," a trader with a refiner said.

Spot market price differentials between Abu Dhabi Murban, a light crude and Dubai crude, which is heavier, was mostly below the key chart level of $1.83 until late November 1996 but has since moved steadily higher.
Japan's crude imports in January totalled 24.31 million kilolitres, up 3.7 percent compared with the same period a year earlier, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI).
Of that, Middle Eastern crudes accounted for 84.5 percent of total January imports, compared with 81.3 percent a month earlier, MITI statistics showed.

In January, the United Arab Emirates was Japan's top supplier, providing 30.1 percent of Japan's crude imports or 7.32 million kilolitres (kl), followed by Saudi Arabia's 21.7 percent, or 5.28 million kl.
Although smaller in volume, imports from countries such as Kuwait and the Neutral Zone, producers of heavy type crudes, grew substantially.
Imports from Kuwait grew 21.6 percent year-on-year, to 1.65 million kl, while imports from the Neutral Zone rose 14.3 percent to 1.37 million kl.
The start-up of secondary facilities at some refineries has also contributed to greater demand for heavier crudes, traders said.
Showa Shell Sekiyu KK last November started operating a residue fluid catalytic cracker (RFCC) at its Yokkaichi plant.
The cracker, which produces gasoline, gas oil and kerosene from fuel oil, has a capacity of 55,000 barrels per day (bpd).
The cracker is expected to save Showa Shell's crude procurement costs substantially, a company spokesman said.
Compared with heavy crudes, light crudes tend to yield a greater amount of middle distillates but are more costly.
Secondary facilities such as crackers, improve the yield of middle distillates, such as gasoline and kerosene, from heavy crudes.
In recent years, Japan's demand for heavy oil products such as fuel oil, mainly used to fuel power plants and boilers, has been falling, while middle distillate demand has been rising.
Tonen Corp said last Friday it planned to start operation of a residual fuel cracking unit with capacity of 25,000 bpd at its Kawasaki refinery by the end of the first-half 1997.
